title: Preparing an Alternative Splicing Annotation for psichomics
text: psichomics quantifies alternative splicing based alternative splicing event annotations MISO, SUPPA, VAST-TOOLS rMATS. New alternative splicing annotation may prepared used psichomics parsing alternative splicing events tools. Please contact like see support tools. tutorial guide parse alternative splicing events different tools. , start loading following packages:

previous_headings: Creating custom alternative splicing annotation
title: Preparing an Alternative Splicing Annotation for psichomics
text: SUPPA generates alternative splicing events based transcript annotation. Start running SUPPA’s generateEvents script transcript file (GTF format) event types, desired. See SUPPA’s page information. resulting output include directory containing tab-delimited files alternative splicing events (one file event type). Hand path directory function parseSuppaAnnotation(), prepare annotation using prepareAnnotationFromEvents() save output RDS file:
code: # suppaOutput <- "path/to/SUPPA/output"  # Replace `genome` for the string with the identifier before the first # underscore in the filenames of that directory (for instance, if one of your  # filenames of interest is "hg19_A3.ioe", the string would be "hg19") suppa <- parseSuppaAnnotation(suppaOutput, genome="hg19") annot <- prepareAnnotationFromEvents(suppa)  # suppaFile <- "suppa_hg19_annotation.RDS" saveRDS(annot, file=suppaFile)

previous_headings: Creating custom alternative splicing annotation
title: Preparing an Alternative Splicing Annotation for psichomics
text: Just like SUPPA, rMATS also allows generate alternative splicing events based transcript annotation, although two BAM FASTQ files required generate alternative splicing events. Read rMATS’ page information. resulting output rMATS handed function parseMatsAnnotation():
code: # matsOutput <- "path/to/rMATS/output" mats <- parseMatsAnnotation(     matsOutput,         # Output directory from rMATS     genome = "fromGTF", # Identifier of the filenames     novelEvents=TRUE)   # Parse novel events? annot <- prepareAnnotationFromEvents(mats)  # matsFile <- "mats_hg19_annotation.RDS" saveRDS(annot, file=matsFile)

previous_headings: Creating custom alternative splicing annotation
title: Preparing an Alternative Splicing Annotation for psichomics
text: Simply retrieve MISO’s alternative splicing annotation give path downloaded folder input.
code: # misoAnnotation <- "path/to/MISO/annotation" miso <- parseMisoAnnotation(misoAnnotation) annot <- prepareAnnotationFromEvents(miso)  # misoFile <- "miso_AS_annotation_hg19.RDS" saveRDS(annot, file=misoFile)

previous_headings: Creating custom alternative splicing annotation
title: Preparing an Alternative Splicing Annotation for psichomics
text: Download extract VAST-TOOLS’ alternative splicing annotation use path TEMPLATES subfolder input parseVastToolsAnnotation(). Complex events (.e. alternative coordinates exon ends) currently supported.
code: # vastAnnotation <- "path/to/VASTDB/libs/TEMPLATES" vast <- parseVastToolsAnnotation(vastAnnotation, genome="Hsa") annot <- prepareAnnotationFromEvents(vast)  # vastFile <- "vast_AS_annotation_hg19.RDS" saveRDS(annot, file=vastFile)

title: Preparing an Alternative Splicing Annotation for psichomics
text: combine annotation different sources, provide parsed annotations interest simultaneously function prepareAnnotationFromEvents:
code: # Combine the annotation from SUPPA, MISO, rMATS and VAST-TOOLS annot <- prepareAnnotationFromEvents(suppa, vast, mats, miso)  # annotFile <- "AS_annotation_hg19.RDS" saveRDS(annot, file=annotFile)

what: Quantifying alternative splicing using the custom annotation
title: Preparing an Alternative Splicing Annotation for psichomics
text: created alternative splicing annotation can used psichomics alternative splicing quantification. , using GUI version psichomics, sure select Load annotation file… option, click button appears select recently created RDS file. Otherwise, using CLI version, perform following steps:
code: annot <- readRDS(annotFile) # "annotFile" is the path to the annotation file junctionQuant <- readFile("ex_junctionQuant.RDS") # example set  psi <- quantifySplicing(annot, junctionQuant) ## Using 1 of 60 events (2%) whose junctions are present in junction quantification data... psi # may have 0 rows because of the small junction quantification set ##                                                   Normal 1  Normal 2 Normal 3 ## SE_1_+_23385660_23385840_23385851_23395032_KDM1A 0.7777778 0.4444444      0.6 ##                                                  Cancer 1  Cancer 2  Cancer 3 ## SE_1_+_23385660_23385840_23385851_23395032_KDM1A      0.4 0.4285714 0.5555556

what: Exploration of clinically-relevant, differentially spliced events in breast cancer
title: Case study: command-line interface (CLI) tutorial
text: following case study adapted psichomics’ original article: Nuno Saraiva-Agostinho Nuno L. Barbosa-Morais (2019). psichomics: graphical application alternative splicing quantification analysis. Nucleic Acids Research. Breast cancer cancer type highest incidence mortality women (Torre et al., 2015) multiple studies suggested transcriptome-wide analyses alternative splicing changes breast tumours able uncover tumour-specific biomarkers (Tsai et al., 2015; Danan-Gotthold et al., 2015; Anczuków et al., 2015). Given relevance early detection breast cancer patient survival, can use psichomics identify novel tumour stage--specific molecular signatures based differentially spliced events.

title: Case study: command-line interface (CLI) tutorial
text: quantification alternative splicing event based proportion junction reads support inclusion isoform, known percent spliced-PSI (Wang et al., 2008). estimate value splicing event, alternative splicing annotation junction quantification required. alternative splicing annotation provided package, junction quantification may retrieved TCGA, GTEx, SRA user-provided files. Data downloaded FireBrowse, service hosts processed data TCGA, required run downstream analyses. downloading data, check following options: Note also option Gene expression (normalised RSEM). However, recommend load raw gene expression data instead, followed filtering normalisation demonstrated afterwards. deciding options use, download load breast cancer data follows: Data downloaded files present given folder. words, files already downloaded, function just load files, possible reuse code just load requested files. Windows limitations: using Windows, note downloaded files huge names may Windows Maximum Path Length. workaround manually rename downloaded files shorter names, move downloaded files single folder load folder.
code: # Available tumour types cohorts <- getFirebrowseCohorts()  # Available sample dates date <- getFirebrowseDates()  # Available data types dataTypes <- getFirebrowseDataTypes() # Set download folder folder <- getDownloadsFolder()  # Download and load most recent junction quantification and clinical data from # TCGA/FireBrowse for Breast Cancer data <- loadFirebrowseData(folder=folder,                            cohort="BRCA",                            data=c("clinical", "junction_quantification",                                   "RSEM_genes"),                            date="2016-01-28") names(data) names(data[[1]])  # Select clinical and junction quantification dataset clinical      <- data[[1]]$`Clinical data` sampleInfo    <- data[[1]]$`Sample metadata` junctionQuant <- data[[1]]$`Junction quantification (Illumina HiSeq)` geneExpr      <- data[[1]]$`Gene expression`

title: Case study: command-line interface (CLI) tutorial
text: package focuses gene expression analysis, suggest read RNA-seq section limma’s user guide. Nevertheless, present following commands quickly filter normalise gene expression:
code: # Check genes with 10 or more counts in at least some samples and 15 or more # total counts across all samples filter <- filterGeneExpr(geneExpr, minCounts=10, minTotalCounts=15)  # What normaliseGeneExpression() does: # 1) Filter gene expression based on its argument "geneFilter" # 2) Normalise gene expression with edgeR::calcNormFactors (internally) using #    the trimmed mean of M-values (TMM) method (by default) # 3) Calculate log2-counts per million (logCPM) geneExprNorm <- normaliseGeneExpression(geneExpr,                                         geneFilter=filter,                                         method="TMM",                                         log2transform=TRUE)

title: Case study: command-line interface (CLI) tutorial
text: loading clinical alternative splicing junction quantification data TCGA, quantify alternative splicing clicking green panel Alternative splicing quantification. previously mentioned, alternative splicing quantified previously loaded junction quantification alternative splicing annotation file. check current annotation files available: Custom splicing annotation: Additional alternative splicing annotations can prepared psichomics parsing annotation programs like VAST-TOOLS, MISO, SUPPA rMATS. Note SUPPA rMATS able create splicing annotation based transcript annotation. Please read Preparing alternative splicing annotations. quantify alternative splicing, first select junction quantification, alternative splicing annotation alternative splicing event type(s) interest: Afterwards, quantify alternative splicing using previously defined parameters: Note event identifier (instance, SE_1_-_2125078_2124414_2124284_2121220_C1orf86) composed : Event type (SE stands skipped exon) Chromosome (1) Strand (-) Relevant coordinates depending event type (case, first constitutive exon’s end, alternative exon’ start end second constitutive exon’s start) Associated gene (C1orf86) Warning: examples shown case study performed using small, yet representative subset available data. Therefore, values shown may correspond performing whole analysis.

title: Case study: command-line interface (CLI) tutorial
text: Let us create groups based available samples types (.e. Metastatic, Primary solid Tumor Solid Tissue Normal) tumour stages. tumour stages divided sub-stages, merge sub-stages tumour samples stages , II, III IV (stage X samples discarded uncharacterised tumour samples).
code: # Group by normal and tumour samples types  <- createGroupByAttribute("Sample types", sampleInfo) normal <- types$`Solid Tissue Normal` tumour <- types$`Primary solid Tumor`  # Group by tumour stage (I, II, III or IV) or normal samples stages <- createGroupByAttribute(     "patient.stage_event.pathologic_stage_tumor_stage", clinical) groups <- list() for (i in c("i", "ii", "iii", "iv")) {     stage <- Reduce(union,            stages[grep(sprintf("stage %s[a|b|c]{0,1}$", i), names(stages))])     # Include only tumour samples     stageTumour <- names(getSubjectFromSample(tumour, stage))     elem <- list(stageTumour)     names(elem) <- paste("Tumour Stage", toupper(i))     groups <- c(groups, elem) } groups <- c(groups, Normal=list(normal))  # Prepare group colours (for consistency across downstream analyses) colours <- c("#6D1F95", "#FF152C", "#00C7BA", "#FF964F", "#00C65A") names(colours) <- names(groups) attr(groups, "Colour") <- colours  # Prepare normal versus tumour stage I samples normalVSstage1Tumour <- groups[c("Tumour Stage I", "Normal")] attr(normalVSstage1Tumour, "Colour") <- attr(groups, "Colour")  # Prepare normal versus tumour samples normalVStumour <- list(Normal=normal, Tumour=tumour) attr(normalVStumour, "Colour") <- c(Normal="#00C65A", Tumour="#EFE35C")

text: PCA technique reduce data dimensionality identifying variable combinations (called principal components) explain variance data (Ringnér, 2008). Use following commands perform PCA: PCA performed data missing values, missing values need either removed (thus discarding data whole splicing events genes) impute (.e. attributing missing values median non-missing ones). Use argument missingValues performPCA() select number missing values tolerable per event (.e. splicing event gene less N missing values, missing values imputed; otherwise, event discarded PCA). performance reasons, loading plot able limit number top variables contribute select principal components, controlled argument nLoadings plotPCA(). Hint: plots psichomics, PCA plots can zoomed-clicking--dragging within plot (click Reset zoom zoom-). toggle visibility data series represented plot, click respective name plot legend. perform PCA using alternative splicing quantification gene expression data (using samples Tumour Stage Normal samples):
code: # PCA of PSI between normal and tumour stage I samples psi_stage1Norm    <- psi[ , unlist(normalVSstage1Tumour)] pcaPSI_stage1Norm <- performPCA(t(psi_stage1Norm)) # Explained variance across principal components plotPCAvariance(pcaPSI_stage1Norm) # Score plot (clinical individuals) plotPCA(pcaPSI_stage1Norm, groups=normalVSstage1Tumour) # Loading plot (variable contributions) plotPCA(pcaPSI_stage1Norm, loadings=TRUE, individuals=FALSE,         nLoadings=100) # Table of variable contributions (as used to plot PCA, also) table <- calculateLoadingsContribution(pcaPSI_stage1Norm) head(table, 5) ## previous_headings: Exploration of clinically-relevant, differentially spliced events in breast cancer > Differential splicing analysis
title: Case study: command-line interface (CLI) tutorial
text: study impact alternative splicing events prognosis, Kaplan-Meier curves may plotted groups patients separated optimal PSI cutoff given alternative splicing event maximises significance group differences survival analysis (.e. minimises p-value log-rank tests difference survival individuals whose samples PSI threshold). Given slow process calculating optimal splicing quantification cutoff multiple events, recommended perform subset differentially spliced events.
code: # Events already tested which have prognostic value events <- c(     "SE_9_+_6486925_6492303_6492401_6493826_UHRF2",     "SE_4_-_87028376_87024397_87024339_87023185_MAPK10",     "SE_2_+_152324660_152324988_152325065_152325155_RIF1",     "SE_2_+_228205096_228217230_228217289_228220393_MFF",     "MXE_15_+_63353138_63353397_63353472_63353912_63353987_63354414_TPM1",     "SE_2_+_173362828_173366500_173366629_173368819_ITGA6",     "SE_1_+_204957934_204971724_204971876_204978685_NFASC")  # Survival curves based on optimal PSI cutoff library(survival)  # Assign alternative splicing quantification to patients based on their samples samples <- colnames(psi) match <- getSubjectFromSample(samples, clinical, sampleInfo=sampleInfo)  survPlots <- list() for (event in events) {     # Find optimal cutoff for the event     eventPSI <- assignValuePerSubject(psi[event, ], match, clinical,                                       samples=unlist(tumour))     opt <- optimalSurvivalCutoff(clinical, eventPSI, censoring="right",                                   event="days_to_death",                                   timeStart="days_to_death")     (optimalCutoff <- opt$par)    # Optimal exon inclusion level     (optimalPvalue <- opt$value)  # Respective p-value          label     <- labelBasedOnCutoff(eventPSI, round(optimalCutoff, 2),                                      label="PSI values")     survTerms <- processSurvTerms(clinical, censoring="right",                                   event="days_to_death",                                    timeStart="days_to_death",                                   group=label, scale="years")     surv <- survfit(survTerms)     pvalue <- testSurvival(survTerms)     survPlots[[event]] <- plotSurvivalCurves(surv, pvalue=pvalue, mark=FALSE) }  # Now print the survival plot of a specific event survPlots[[ events[[1]] ]]

title: Case study: command-line interface (CLI) tutorial
text: Detected alterations alternative splicing may simply reflection changes gene expression levels. Therefore, disentangle two effects, differential expression analysis tumour stage normal samples also performed. order :
code: # Prepare groups of samples to analyse and further filter unavailable samples in # selected groups for gene expression ge           <- geneExprNorm[ , unlist(normalVSstage1Tumour), drop=FALSE] isFromGroup1 <- colnames(ge) %in% normalVSstage1Tumour[[1]] design       <- cbind(1, ifelse(isFromGroup1, 0, 1))  # Fit a gene-wise linear model based on selected groups library(limma) fit <- lmFit(as.matrix(ge), design)  # Calculate moderated t-statistics and DE log-odds using limma::eBayes ebayesFit <- eBayes(fit, trend=TRUE)  # Prepare data summary pvalueAdjust <- "BH" # Benjamini-Hochberg p-value adjustment (FDR) summary <- topTable(ebayesFit, number=nrow(fit), coef=2, sort.by="none",                     adjust.method=pvalueAdjust, confint=TRUE) names(summary) <- c("log2 Fold-Change", "CI (low)", "CI (high)",                      "Average expression", "moderated t-statistics", "p-value",                      paste0("p-value (", pvalueAdjust, " adjusted)"),                     "B-statistics") attr(summary, "groups") <- normalVSstage1Tumour  # Calculate basic statistics stats <- diffAnalyses(ge, normalVSstage1Tumour, "basicStats",                        pvalueAdjust=NULL) final <- cbind(stats, summary)  # Differential gene expression between breast tumour stage I and normal samples library(ggplot2) library(ggrepel) cognateGenes <- unlist(parseSplicingEvent(events)$gene) logFCthreshold  <- abs(final$`log2 Fold-Change`) > 1 pvalueThreshold <- final$`p-value (BH adjusted)` < 0.01  final$genes <- gsub("\\|.*$", "\\1", rownames(final)) ggplot(final, aes(`log2 Fold-Change`,                    -log10(`p-value (BH adjusted)`))) +     geom_point(data=final[logFCthreshold & pvalueThreshold, ],                colour="orange", alpha=0.5, size=3) +      geom_point(data=final[!logFCthreshold | !pvalueThreshold, ],                colour="gray", alpha=0.5, size=3) +      geom_text_repel(data=final[cognateGenes, ], aes(label=genes),                     box.padding=0.4, size=5) +     theme_light(16) +     ylab("-log10(q-value)")

text: study impact alternative splicing events prognosis, Kaplan-Meier curves may plotted groups patients separated given PSI cutoff given alternative splicing event. optimal PSI cutoff maximises significance group differences survival analysis (.e.  minimises p-value log-rank tests difference survival individuals whose samples PSI threshold). per results, higher inclusion UHRF2 exon 10 associated better prognosis.
code: # Find optimal cutoff for the event UHRF2skippedExon10 <- events[1] eventPSI <- assignValuePerSubject(psi[UHRF2skippedExon10, ], match, clinical,                                   samples=unlist(tumour)) opt <- optimalSurvivalCutoff(clinical, eventPSI, censoring="right",                               event="days_to_death", timeStart="days_to_death") (optimalCutoff <- opt$par)    # Optimal exon inclusion level ## [1] 0.1436954 (optimalPvalue <- opt$value)  # Respective p-value ## [1] 0.0358 label     <- labelBasedOnCutoff(eventPSI, round(optimalCutoff, 2),                                  label="PSI values") survTerms <- processSurvTerms(clinical, censoring="right",                               event="days_to_death", timeStart="days_to_death",                               group=label, scale="years") surv <- survfit(survTerms) pvalue <- testSurvival(survTerms) plotSurvivalCurves(surv, pvalue=pvalue, mark=FALSE)

code: UHRF2ge <- assignValuePerSubject(geneExprNorm["UHRF2", ], match, clinical,                                   samples=unlist(tumour))  # Survival curves based on optimal gene expression cutoff opt <- optimalSurvivalCutoff(clinical, UHRF2ge, censoring="right",                              event="days_to_death", timeStart="days_to_death") (optimalCutoff <- opt$par)    # Optimal exon inclusion level ## [1] 10.42619 (optimalPvalue <- opt$value)  # Respective p-value ## [1] 0.176 # Process again after rounding the cutoff roundedCutoff <- round(optimalCutoff, 2) label     <- labelBasedOnCutoff(UHRF2ge, roundedCutoff, label="Gene expression") survTerms <- processSurvTerms(clinical, censoring="right",                               event="days_to_death", timeStart="days_to_death",                               group=label, scale="years") surv   <- survfit(survTerms) pvalue <- testSurvival(survTerms) plotSurvivalCurves(surv, pvalue=pvalue, mark=FALSE)

Data SRA can downloaded using fasterq-dump command sra-tools. instance, retrieve samples SRP126561 project: --split-3 allows output one two FASTQ files single-end paired-end sequencing, respectively (third FASTQ file may also returned containing orphaned single-end reads obtained paired-end sequencing data) Sample-associated data also available Run Selector page. Click RunInfo Table download whole metadata table samples (usually downloaded file named SraRunTable.txt).
code: # List SRA samples samples=(SRR6368612 SRR6368613 SRR6368614 SRR6368615 SRR6368616 SRR6368617)  # Download samples fasterq-dump --split-3 ${samples}

previous_headings: Supported file formats > Prepare tables based on RNA-seq data using STAR > Align RNA-seq data to quantify splice junctions
title: Loading user-provided data
text: aligning FASTQ samples genome reference, index needs prepared. Start downloading FASTA file whole genome GTF file annotated transcripts. command makes use human FASTA GTF files (hg19 assembly).
code: mkdir hg19_STAR STAR --runMode genomeGenerate \      --genomeDir hg19_STAR \      --genomeFastaFiles /path/to/hg19.fa \      --sjdbGTFfile /path/to/hg19.gtf \      --runThreadN 4  # Arguments: #     --runMode             Generate the genome index #     --genomeDir           Path to genome index (output) #     --genomeFastaFiles    Path to genome FASTA file(s) #     --sjdbGTFfile         Path to junction GTF annotation #     --runThreadN 4        Run in parallel using 4 threads

previous_headings: Supported file formats > Prepare tables based on RNA-seq data using STAR > Align RNA-seq data to quantify splice junctions
what: Align against genome index using STAR
title: Loading user-provided data
text: genome index generated, sequences FASTQ files need aligned annotated gene splice junctions previously prepared reference. following commands make STAR output gene junction read counts files ending ReadsPerGene..tab SJ..tab, respectively.
code: align () {     echo "Aligning ${1} using STAR..."     STAR --readFilesIn ${1}_1.fastq ${1}_2.fastq \          --runThreadN 16 \          --genomeDir hg19_STAR \          --readFilesCommand zcat \          --quantMode GeneCounts \          --outFileNamePrefix ${1} } # Arguments: #     --readFilesIn              FASTQ files to align #     --runThreadN 16            Run in parallel using 16 threads #     --genomeDir                Path to genome index (input) #     --readFilesCommand zcat    Use zcat to extract compressed files #     --quantMode                Return gene read counts #     --outFileNamePrefix        Prefix for output files           for each in ${samples}; do     align "${each}" done

title: Loading user-provided data
text: psichomics supports loading inclusion levels gene expression tables VAST-TOOLS (tables available running vast-tools combine). Note: interested analysing gene expression, please run vast-tools align argument --expr; Gene expression returned cRPKMs; get cRPKMs gene read counts, please run vast-tools combine argument -C (case doubt, always calculate cRPKMs gene read counts). sample /subject information may also useful load. Unless sample metadata comes SRA Run Selector, please ensure table recognised psichomics: read Prepare generic data. load data move files new folder (VAST-TOOLS alternative splicing quantification gene expression tables sample/subject-associated information). Follow instructions Load user-provided data psichomics load files visual interface. Otherwise, use function loadLocalFiles() folder path argument:
code: library(psichomics) data <- loadLocalFiles("/path/to/psichomics/input") names(data) names(data[[1]])  junctionQuant  <- data[[1]]$`Junction quantification` sampleInfo     <- data[[1]]$`Sample metadata` # Both gene read counts and cRPKMs are loaded as separate data frames geneReadCounts <- data[[1]]$`Gene expression (read counts)` cRPKM          <- data[[1]]$`Gene expression (cRPKM)`

what: Visual interface for alternative splicing analysis and visualisation
title: Visual interface for alternative splicing analysis and visualisation
text: Original article: Nuno Saraiva-Agostinho Nuno L. Barbosa-Morais (2019). psichomics: graphical application alternative splicing quantification analysis. Nucleic Acids Research. 47(2), e7. Interactive R package intuitive Shiny-based graphical interface alternative splicing quantification integrative analyses alternative splicing gene expression based Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA), Genotype-Tissue Expression (GTEx) project, Sequence Read Archive (SRA) user-provided data. psichomics interactively performs: - Dimensionality reduction - Median- variance-based differential splicing gene expression analyses - Survival analysis - Correlation analysis - Grouping clinical molecular features (tumour stage survival) - Genomic mapping functional annotation alternative splicing events genes Differential splicing analysis psichomics

text: Molecular clinical sample-associated attributes allow establish groups can explored data analyses. instance, TCGA data can analysed based smoking history, gender race, among attributes. Groups can also manipulated (e.g. merged, intersected, etc.), allowing complex attribute combinations. Groups can also saved loaded different sessions.

previous_headings: Workflow
title: Visual interface for alternative splicing analysis and visualisation
text: Dimensionality reduction via principal independent component analysis (PCA ICA) alternative splicing quantification gene expression. Differential splicing gene expression analysis based variance median parametric non-parametric statistical tests. Correlation gene expression splicing quantification, useful correlate expression given event expression RNA-binding proteins, instance. Survival analysis via Kaplan-Meier curves Cox models based sample-associated features. Additionally, can study impact splicing event (based quantification) gene (based expression) patient survivability. Gene, transcript protein annotation, including relevant research articles.

text: Show progress bar running command-line interface Fix inconsistent browser history navigation Updated CLI vignette information analysing gene expression data quick reference functions Update minimum version required shiny (1.0.3) Avoid replacing selected groups manipulating new ones Fix data rendered table zooming plot data transformation applied Return p-value NA instead 0 value Fligner-Killeen’s Test Homogeneity Variance infinite Discard value transformations may return invalid data values chosen X Y axes Fix point remains highlighted plot deselecting selected row table Improve readability plot’s tooltip Include survival curve previews 3 new columns within differential splicing analyses table, instead table; columns consist survival curves, optimal PSI cutoff respective log-rank test’s p-value Allow use survival data plotting table sorting Include optimal PSI cutoff respective log-rank test’s p-value exported tables Fix link survival analyses using previously calculated PSI cutoff clicking alternative splicing event loadings plot, appropriate differential splicing analyses now automatically rendered respective options, expected Properly set title survival curves based selected splicing event’s quantification Improve readability Cox PH models performing survival analyses alternative splicing cutoff, patient assigned PSI value respective sample; patients one sample, assigned sample chosen based frequent sample type across patients (, first matched non-normal non-control samples used) Multiple bug fixes visual improvements

title: Version 1.4
text: Add input elements allow GTEx gene expression loading graphical interface Fix bug allow select tissues load GTEx v7 data (graphical interface) Fix splicing events quantified based GTEx v7 junction reads Fix misleading gene expression (non-)normalisation converting reads counts per million (CPM) using edgeR::cpm() normalisation using edgeR::calcNormFactor() Updated support properly parse new notation alternative splicing annotation Bioconductor (backwards compatible older notation) Raise error splicing events quantification Fix warning following quantification splicing events loading (incorrect parsing gene information splicing events) Use number (instead percentage) tolerated missing values per sample argument impute data remaining samples values performing dimensionality reduction; default, missing values tolerated 10 samples Update file description README Minor bug fixes improvements

title: Version 1.4
text: Fix error trying load alternative splicing annotation (given updated hg19 hg38 annotation now available use psichomics)

title: Version 1.4
text: Improve speed memory usage dealing larger datasets Improve quantification alternative first last exons: quantify alternative first last exons based exon-exon junction reads support alternative exons Print progress bar R console Change tolerated missing values per event 5% default Show/save table contribution events (alternative splicing quantification) genes (gene expression) selected principal components Add extra information hovering variables loading plot Allow plot top 100 variables contribute selected principal components (faster rendering interaction loading plots) Allow input list groups “group” argument functions diffAnalyses() plotDistribution() (command-line interface) Allow input non-numeric vector row matrix/data frame “data” argument function plotDistribution() (command-line interface) Perform correlation gene expression multiple genes quantification multiple alternative splicing events

previous_headings: psichomics 1.4.3 (12 Jan, 2018)
title: Version 1.4
text: Fix unnamed events one event event type returned Minor copy-editing overall improvements

title: Version 1.4
text: Update CITATION file show citation article bioRxiv: https://www.biorxiv.org/content/early/2018/02/07/261180 Update vignettes include case study based aforementioned article Perform limma-trend default Quantification alternative first last exons: following thorough testing, new exon-centred method considered less relevant exploratory analysis (specially compared types events); , methods now available quantification Change tolerated missing values per event 5% default PCA ICA (visual command-line interfaces) PCA: table shows events contribute selected principal components, show rank Automatically set sample type groups (.e. normal, primary solid tumour, metastatic, etc.) TCGA samples (visual interface ) Use numeric fields instead sliders precisely filter data Fix table differential expression filtered based highlighted genes Filter splicing events genes use performing exploratory differential analyses Allow stratify patients based optimal gene expression cutoff Select samples used survival analysis

previous_headings: psichomics 1.4.4 (12 Feb, 2018)
title: Version 1.4
text: Groups displayed attributes last created group Table updated differential analyses according event filtering based volcano plot

title: Version 1.4
text: Mention psichomics manuscript throughout psichomics Copy-edit graphical user interface respective tutorial Fix warnings errors Bioconductor

title: Version 1.6
text: New tutorial performing alternative splicing analysis using SRA user-provided data FASTQ files (tutorials also updated) Process gene splice junction counts STAR output subsequent loading psichomics Automatically download load data select SRA projects using recount R package Preview groups based selected attribute creation Display alternative splicing events transcript plot Allow change plot height font size

previous_headings: psichomics 1.6.1 (5 July, 2018)
title: Version 1.6
text: Support new version Human (hg38 assembly) alternative splicing annotation (fixes wrong coordinates many minus-strand splicing events) sample metadata loaded loading TCGA files local folder retrieving sample metadata TCGA samples multiple junction quantification files loaded Correctly suggest select variables subset expression give examples use feature Fix subject/sample attributes updated selection GREP interface Fix error alerts appearing trying create groups based invalid parameters Add error alert trying extract group data user-provided file without information Fix crash quantifying splicing single sample Fix crash inputting non-numeric values minimum larger maximum limit axes splicing scatter plot

title: Version 1.6
text: Update citations link article Nucleic Acids Research: https://doi.org/10.1093/nar/gky888 Copy-edit README, tutorials, DESCRIPTION, NEWS code Update screen shot Add metadata regarding loaded datasets (instance, path name files used dataset loading, options set upon dataset creation, etc.) Allow input formulas highlighting points; improvement plotting -log10(q-values), instance, now possible highlight values >= -log10(0.05), .e. q-values <= 0.5, instead inputting approximate value Colour samples group Render contour based density estimate Display exportable table correlation analyses Show group colour group selection element Retrieve articles PubMed instead PMC

previous_headings: psichomics 1.6.2 (2 October, 2018)
title: Version 1.6
text: Allow directly input path without using file browser dialog Display warning calling file browser dialog RStudio Server unsupported system Inform sequencing technology used obtain gene expression data Fix issues downstream analyses using GTEx data subset tissues Avoid limiting X axis density plot values outside 0 1 provided, case gene expression (plotDistribution() function) Fix filenames exported tables differential expression analysis incorrectly mentioning differential splicing analysis instead plotting correlation analysis, loess curve performed based gaussian fitting, independent “family” argument plotCorrelation() Improve console logging error warning messages

title: Version 1.8
text: Add tag ImmunoOncology BiocViews

title: Version 1.8
text: GTEx data can now automatically downloaded loaded -demand default, data table now displays first 100 columns performance reasons Allow discard samples alternative splicing quantification alternative splicing quantification dataset summary, plot quantification based median, variance range per splicing event across samples provide tools filter quantification (plotRowStats()) Allow discard samples filtering normalisation Filter low read counts using edgeR::filterByExpr() Allow perform limma::voom() gene expression data (without design matrix) apply normalisation methods gene expression dataset summary, plot distribution gene expression per sample, distribution library sizes gene-wise mean variance gene expression across samples provide user tools assess gene expression normalisation (plotGeneExprPerSample(), plotDistribution() plotRowStats(), respectively) Convert different gene identifiers (original identifier kept conditions, read convertGeneIdentifiers()); visual interface, filtering normalising gene expression, ENSEMBL identifiers converted gene symbols, default default, load pre-made lists genes loading gene expression loading/performing alternative splicing quantification Added pre-made list genes encode RNA-binding proteins (Sebestyen et al. 2016), useful postulate regulatory role proteins based gene expression PSI correlation analyses Allow use groups genes alternative splicing events correlation analyses Plot specific combinations gene alternative splicing events ([.GEandAScorrelation()) Display progress performing correlation analyses Display correlation results table (.table()) Render p-value plot cutoff command-line interface (plotSurvivalPvaluesByCutoff()) Modify keywords used search PubMed articles

previous_headings: psichomics 1.8.2 (26 March, 2019)
title: Version 1.8
text: Improve console logging error warning alerts Fix crash loading psichomics test data locally available (automatically downloading said data found) Allow edit file path file/directory browser elements Export functions mentioned documentation Hide documentation internal functions PDF reference manual Accept vector files first argument (easier use list.files()) Ask overwrite file one exists name output file Automatically set dropdown width group attribute selection Minor improvements group creation interface Fix error creating groups containing samples matching subjects Fix warning displaying group preview based subjects samples Automatically set human genome version loading data TCGA (hg19), GTEx (hg19) recount2 (hg38) Fix progress bar Decrease loading time quantifying alternative splicing default, quantify skipped exons, mutually exclusive exons, alternative 3’ 5’ splice sites, alternative first last exons; default option now consistent across visual command-line interfaces) Allow distribution plots show name samples hovering rug plot rendered rugLabels = TRUE (function plotDistribution()) Fix distribution plots requiring samples group using function plotDistribution() Fix group colours opacity rug plot points within distribution plot (occurred command-line version; function plotDistribution()) Fix wrong information table differential splicing results (occurs first splicing event one enough information calculate statistical tests) Fix inconsistency presenting median variance differences gene expression alternative splicing quantification Fix error groups contain samples outside data analysed Fix article title formatting (e.g. bold italics) Update psichomics citation journal publication date

title: Assign average sample values to their corresponding subjects — assignValuePerSubject
text: Values per subject

title: Assign average sample values to their corresponding subjects — assignValuePerSubject
code: # Calculate PSI for skipped exon (SE) and mutually exclusive (MXE) events annot <- readFile("ex_splicing_annotation.RDS") junctionQuant <- readFile("ex_junctionQuant.RDS")  psi <- quantifySplicing(annot, junctionQuant, eventType=c("SE", "MXE")) #> Using 3 of 3 events (100%) whose junctions are present in junction quantification data... #>   |                                        |   0%    |========                                |  20%    |================                        |  40%    |========================                |  60%    |================================        |  80%    |========================================| 100%  #> Using 3 of 3 events (100%) whose junctions are present in junction quantification data... #>   |                                        |   0%    |========                                |  20%    |================                        |  40%    |========================                |  60%    |================================        |  80%    |========================================| 100%   # Match between subjects and samples match <- rep(paste("Subject", 1:3), 2) names(match) <- colnames(psi)  # Assign PSI values to each subject based on the PSI of their samples assignValuePerSubject(psi[3, ], match) #> Subject 1 Subject 2 Subject 3  #> 0.4336962 0.4815878 0.3925439

title: Get or set globally accessible elements — getGlobal
text: category Character: data category ... Arguments identify variable sep Character separate identifiers value Value attribute element data Matrix data frame: alternative splicing information name Character: data table name auto Boolean: enable automatic navigation browser history? integer Integer: value setting ah AnnotationHub event Character: alternative splicing event dataset Character: dataset name attrs Character: name attributes retrieve (NULL, whole dataset returned) item Character: name specific item retrieve (NULL, whole list returned) EList Boolean: return gene expression datasets EList possible data frames? geneExpr Data frame matrix: normalised gene expression incLevels Data frame matrix: inclusion levels cache List summary statistics pca prcomp object (principal component analysis) ica Object containing independent component analysis correlation prcomp object (correlation analyses) groupIndependenceTesting Object containing group independence testing results species Character: species assembly Character: assembly version annotName Character: annotation name url Character: URL links download

title: Plot survival curves — hchart.survfit

Arguments passed highcharter::hc_add_series   fun Name function function used transform survival curve: log put y axis log scale, event plots cumulative events (f(y) = 1-y), cumhaz plots cumulative hazard function (f(y) = -log(y)), cloglog creates complimentary log-log survival plot (f(y) = log(-log(y)) along log scale x-axis. markTimes Label curves marked censoring time? symbol Symbol use marker markerColor Colour marker; NULL, respective colour series used ranges Plot interval ranges? rangesOpacity Opacity interval ranges

code: vals <- sample(30, replace=TRUE) group <- lapply(list("A", "B", "C"), rep, 10) group <- unlist(group) psichomics:::leveneTest(vals, group) #>  #> 	Levene's test (using the median) #>  #> data:  vals and group #> W = 0.64408, p-value = 0.533 #>   ## Using Levene's test based on the mean psichomics:::leveneTest(vals, group, mean) #>  #> 	Levene's test (using the mean) #>  #> data:  vals and group #> W = 0.95636, p-value = 0.3969 #>

what: Filter and normalise gene expression — normaliseGeneExpression
title: Filter and normalise gene expression — normaliseGeneExpression
text: Gene expression filtered normalised following steps: Filter gene expression; Normalise gene expression calcNormFactors; performVoom = FALSE, compute counts per million (CPM) using cpm log2-transform values log2transform = TRUE; performVoom = TRUE, use voom compute log2-CPM, quantile-normalise (method = "quantile") estimate mean-variance relationship calculate observation-level weights.

title: Filter and normalise gene expression — normaliseGeneExpression
code: normaliseGeneExpression(   geneExpr,   geneFilter = NULL,   method = "TMM",   p = 0.75,   log2transform = TRUE,   priorCount = 0.25,   performVoom = FALSE )  normalizeGeneExpression(   geneExpr,   geneFilter = NULL,   method = "TMM",   p = 0.75,   log2transform = TRUE,   priorCount = 0.25,   performVoom = FALSE )

title: Filter and normalise gene expression — normaliseGeneExpression
text: geneExpr Matrix data frame: gene expression geneFilter Boolean: filtered genes (NULL, skip filtering) method Character: normalisation method, including TMM, RLE, upperquartile, none quantile (see Details) p numeric value 0 1 specifying quantile counts used method="upperquartile". log2transform Boolean: perform log2-transformation? priorCount Average count add observation avoid zeroes log-transformation performVoom Boolean: perform mean-variance modelling (using voom)?

title: Filter and normalise gene expression — normaliseGeneExpression
text: Filtered normalised gene expression

title: Filter and normalise gene expression — normaliseGeneExpression
text: edgeR::calcNormFactors used normalise gene expression method TMM, RLE, upperquartile none. performVoom = TRUE, voom normalise method = "quantile". Available normalisation methods: TMM recommended RNA-seq data half genes believed differentially expressed pair samples; RLE calculates median library geometric mean columns median ratio sample median library taken scale factor; upperquartile calculates scale factors given quantile counts library, removing genes zero counts libraries; quantile forces entire empirical distribution column identical (performed performVoom = TRUE).

title: Calculate optimal data cutoff that best separates survival curves — optimalSurvivalCutoff
text: clinical Data frame: clinical data data Numeric: data values censoring Character: censor using left, right, interval interval2 event Character: name column containing time event interest timeStart Character: name column containing starting time interval follow time timeStop Character: name column containing ending time interval (relevant interval censoring) followup Character: name column containing follow time session Shiny session (used visual interface) filter Boolean numeric: elements use (used default) survTime survTime object: times follow , time start, time stop event (optional) lower, upper Bounds search (NULL, bounds set lower = 0 upper = 1 data values within interval; otherwise, lower = min(data, na.rm = TRUE) upper = max(data, na.rm = TRUE))

title: Calculate optimal data cutoff that best separates survival curves — optimalSurvivalCutoff
text: List containing optimal cutoff (par) corresponding p-value (value)

title: Calculate optimal data cutoff that best separates survival curves — optimalSurvivalCutoff
code: clinical <- read.table(text = "2549   NA ii  female                                 840   NA i   female                                  NA 1204 iv    male                                  NA  383 iv  female                                1293   NA iii   male                                  NA 1355 ii    male") names(clinical) <- c("patient.days_to_last_followup",                      "patient.days_to_death",                      "patient.stage_event.pathologic_stage",                      "patient.gender") timeStart  <- "days_to_death" event      <- "days_to_death"  psi <- c(0.1, 0.2, 0.9, 1, 0.2, 0.6) opt <- optimalSurvivalCutoff(clinical, psi, "right", event, timeStart)

code: # Parse generic event (in this case, an exon skipping event) junctions <- read.table(text=     "79685787 79685910 79685796 79685910 79679566 79679751") coords <- c("A1.start", "A1.end",             "C1.start", "C1.end",             "C2.start", "C2.end") plus  <- c(1:6) minus <- c(2:1, 6:3) psichomics:::parseMatsGeneric(junctions, strand = "+", coords, plus, minus) #>   C1.start   C1.end A1.start   A1.end A2.start A2.end C2.start   C2.end #> 1 79685796 79685910 79685787 79685910       NA     NA 79679566 79679751  # Parse exon skipping event junctions <- read.table(text=     "79685787 79685910 79685796 79685910 79679566 79679751") psichomics:::parseMatsSE(junctions, strand = "+") #>   C1.start   C1.end A1.start   A1.end A2.start A2.end C2.start   C2.end #> 1 79685796 79685910 79685787 79685910       NA     NA 79679566 79679751  # Parse mutually exclusive exon event junctions <- read.table(text= "158282161 158282276 158282689 158282804 158281047 158281295 158283950 158284199") psichomics:::parseMatsMXE(junctions, strand = "+") #>    C1.start    C1.end  A1.start    A1.end  A2.start    A2.end  C2.start #> 1 158281047 158281295 158282161 158282276 158282689 158282804 158283950 #>      C2.end #> 1 158284199  # Parse retained intron event junctions <- read.table(text=     "15929853 15932100 15929853 15930016 15930687 15932100") psichomics:::parseMatsRI(junctions, strand = "+") #>   C1.start   C1.end A1.start A1.end A2.start A2.end C2.start   C2.end #> 1 15929853 15930016       NA     NA       NA     NA 15930687 15932100  # Parse alternative 3' splicing site event junctions <- read.table(text=     "79685787 79685910 79685796 79685910 79679566 79679751") psichomics:::parseMatsA3SS(junctions, strand = "+") #>   C1.start   C1.end A1.start A1.end A2.start   A2.end C2.start C2.end #> 1 79679566 79679751 79685787     NA 79685796 79685910       NA     NA  # code: junctions <- read.table(text = "41040823 41046768 41046903 41051785") psichomics:::parseVastToolsSE(junctions) #>   C1.start   C1.end A1.start   A1.end A2.start A2.end C2.start C2.end Strand #> 1       NA 41040823 41046768 41046903       NA     NA 41051785     NA      +  # these functions are vectorised! junctions <- read.table(text = "41040823 41046768 41046903 41051785                                 58864658 58864693 58864294 58864563") psichomics:::parseVastToolsSE(junctions) #>   C1.start   C1.end A1.start   A1.end A2.start A2.end C2.start C2.end Strand #> 1       NA 41040823 41046768 41046903       NA     NA 41051785     NA      + #> 2       NA 58864658 58864294 58864693       NA     NA 58864563     NA      -  junctions <- read.table(text = "58864658 58864693 58864294 58864563") psichomics:::parseVastToolsRI(junctions, strand = "+") #>   C1.start   C1.end A1.start A1.end A2.start A2.end C2.start   C2.end Strand #> 1 58864658 58864693       NA     NA       NA     NA 58864294 58864563      +  junctions <- rbind(     c(36276385, list(c(36277798, 36277315)), 36277974),     c(7133604, 7133377, list(c(7133474, 7133456))) ) psichomics:::parseVastToolsA3SS(junctions) #>   C1.start   C1.end A1.start A1.end A2.start   A2.end C2.start C2.end Strand #> 1       NA 36276385 36277798     NA 36277315 36277974       NA     NA      + #> 2       NA  7133604  7133474     NA  7133456  7133377       NA     NA      -  junctions <- rbind(     c(74650610, list(c(74650654, 74650658)), 74650982),     c(list(c(49557666, 49557642), 49557746, 49557470)) ) psichomics:::parseVastToolsA5SS(junctions) #>   C1.start C1.end A1.start   A1.end A2.start   A2.end C2.start C2.end Strand #> 1       NA     NA       NA 74650654 74650610 74650658 74650982     NA      + #> 2       NA     NA       NA 49557666 49557746 49557642 49557470     NA      -

text: data optional data frame (similar: see     model.frame) containing variables     formula formula.  default variables taken     environment(formula). n.comp number components extracted center logical value indicating whether variables     shifted zero centered. Alternatively, vector length     equal number columns x can supplied.      value passed scale. missingValues Integer: number tolerated missing values per column replaced mean values column alg.typ alg.typ == "parallel" components extracted     simultaneously (default). alg.typ == "deflation"     components extracted one time. fun functional form \(G\) function used     approximation neg-entropy (see ‘details’). alpha constant range [1, 2] used approximation     neg-entropy fun == "logcosh" ... FALSE, axis relative PSI values range 0 1 loessSmooth Boolean: plot smooth curve computed stats::loess.smooth? loessFamily Character: gaussian, loess fitting least-squares, symmetric, re-descending M estimator used colour Character: points' colour alpha Numeric: points' alpha size Numeric: points' size loessColour Character: loess line's colour loessAlpha Numeric: loess line's opacity loessWidth Numeric: loess line's width fontSize Numeric: plot font size ... Arguments passed stats::loess.smooth span smoothness parameter loess. degree degree local polynomial used. evaluation number points evaluate smooth     curve. colourGroups List characters: sample colouring group legend Boolean: show legend sample colouring? showAllData Boolean: show data outside selected groups single group (coloured based colour argument) density Boolean: contour plot density estimate densityColour Character: line colour contours densityWidth Numeric: line width contours pvalueAdjust Character: method used adjust p-values (see Details)

text: Plots, summary tables results correlation analyses

title: Display results of correlation analyses — [.GEandAScorrelation
text: following methods p-value adjustment supported using respective string pvalueAdjust argument: none: adjust p-values BH: Benjamini-Hochberg's method (false discovery rate) : Benjamini-Yekutieli's method (false discovery rate) bonferroni: Bonferroni correction (family-wise error rate) holm: Holm's method (family-wise error rate) hochberg: Hochberg's method (family-wise error rate) hommel: Hommel's method (family-wise error rate)

title: Display results of correlation analyses — [.GEandAScorrelation
code: annot <- readFile("ex_splicing_annotation.RDS") junctionQuant <- readFile("ex_junctionQuant.RDS") psi <- quantifySplicing(annot, junctionQuant, eventType=c("SE", "MXE")) #> Using 3 of 3 events (100%) whose junctions are present in junction quantification data... #>   |                                        |   0%    |========                                |  20%    |================                        |  40%    |========================                |  60%    |================================        |  80%    |========================================| 100%  #> Using 3 of 3 events (100%) whose junctions are present in junction quantification data... #>   |                                        |   0%    |========                                |  20%    |================                        |  40%    |========================                |  60%    |================================        |  80%    |========================================| 100%   geneExpr <- readFile("ex_gene_expression.RDS") corr <- correlateGEandAS(geneExpr, psi, "ALDOA")  # Quick display of the correlation results per splicing event and gene print(corr) #> ================================================================================ #> SE_2_+_32_35_37_38_ALDOA splicing event #> ALDOA|226 gene expression #>  #> 	Pearson's product-moment correlation #>  #> data:  exprNum and eventPSInum #> t = -0.7542, df = 4, p-value = 0.4927 #> alternative hypothesis: true correlation is not equal to 0 #> 95 percent confidence interval: #>  -0.9051981  0.6427793 #> sample estimates: #>        cor  #> -0.3528456  #>  #> ================================================================================ #> MXE_2_+_32_35_37_38_40_42_ALDOA splicing event #> ALDOA|226 gene expression #>  #> 	Pearson's product-moment correlation #>  #> data:  exprNum and eventPSInum #> t = -0.26642, df = 4, p-value = 0.8031 #> alternative hypothesis: true correlation is not equal to 0 #> 95 percent confidence interval: #>  -0.8522745  0.7610748 #> sample estimates: #>        cor  #> -0.1320457  #>   # Table summarising the correlation analysis results as.table(corr) #>        Alternative splicing event      Gene #> 1        SE 2 + 32 35 37 38 ALDOA ALDOA|226 #> 2 MXE 2 + 32 35 37 38 40 42 ALDOA ALDOA|226 #>   Pearson's product-moment correlation   p-value p-value (BH adjusted) #> 1                           -0.3528456 0.4926962             0.8030827 #> 2                           -0.1320457 0.8030827             0.8030827  # Correlation analysis plots colourGroups <- list(Normal=paste("Normal", 1:3),                      Tumour=paste("Cancer", 1:3)) attr(colourGroups, "Colour") <- c(Normal="#00C65A", Tumour="#EEE273") plot(corr, colourGroups=colourGroups, alpha=1) #> $`SE_2_+_32_35_37_38_ALDOA` #> $`SE_2_+_32_35_37_38_ALDOA`$`ALDOA|226`  #>  #>  #> $`MXE_2_+_32_35_37_38_40_42_ALDOA` #> $`MXE_2_+_32_35_37_38_40_42_ALDOA`$`ALDOA|226`  #>  #>

title: Plot row-wise statistics — plotRowStats
text: Scatter plot compare row-wise mean, median, variance range data frame matrix. Also supports transformations variables, log10(mean). y = NULL, density plot rendered instead.

title: Plot row-wise statistics — plotRowStats
code: plotRowStats(   data,   x,   y = NULL,   subset = NULL,   xmin = NULL,   xmax = NULL,   ymin = NULL,   ymax = NULL,   xlim = NULL,   ylim = NULL,   cache = NULL,   verbose = FALSE,   data2 = NULL,   legend = FALSE,   legendLabels = c("Original", "Highlighted") )

title: Plot row-wise statistics — plotRowStats
text: data Data frame matrix containing samples per column , instance, gene alternative splicing event per row x, y Character: statistic calculate display plot per row; choose mean, median, var range (transformations variables, e.g. log10(var)); y = NULL, density x plot instead subset Boolean integer: data points highlight xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax Numeric: minimum maximum X Y values draw plot xlim, ylim Numeric: X Y axis range cache List summary statistics data previously calculated avoid repeating calculations (output also returns cache attribute named cache appropriate data) verbose Boolean: print messages steps performed data2 data argument points data2 highlighted (unless data2 = NULL) legend Boolean: show legend? legendLabels Character: legend labels

title: Plot row-wise statistics — plotRowStats
text: Plot data

title: Plot row-wise statistics — plotRowStats
code: library(ggplot2)  # Plotting gene expression data geneExpr <- readFile("ex_gene_expression.RDS") plotRowStats(geneExpr, "mean", "var^(1/4)") +     ggtitle("Mean-variance plot") +     labs(y="Square Root of the Standard Deviation")   # Plotting alternative splicing quantification annot <- readFile("ex_splicing_annotation.RDS") junctionQuant <- readFile("ex_junctionQuant.RDS") psi <- quantifySplicing(annot, junctionQuant, eventType=c("SE", "MXE")) #> Using 3 of 3 events (100%) whose junctions are present in junction quantification data... #>   |                                        |   0%    |========                                |  20%    |================                        |  40%    |========================                |  60%    |================================        |  80%    |========================================| 100%  #> Using 3 of 3 events (100%) whose junctions are present in junction quantification data... #>   |                                        |   0%    |========                                |  20%    |================                        |  40%    |========================                |  60%    |================================        |  80%    |========================================| 100%   medianVar <- plotRowStats(psi, x="median", y="var", xlim=c(0, 1)) +     labs(x="Median PSI", y="PSI variance") medianVar   rangeVar  <- plotRowStats(psi, x="range", y="log10(var)", xlim=c(0, 1)) +     labs(x="PSI range", y="log10(PSI variance)") rangeVar

code: clinical <- read.table(text = "2549   NA ii  female                                 840   NA i   female                                  NA 1204 iv    male                                  NA  383 iv  female                                1293   NA iii   male") names(clinical) <- c("patient.days_to_last_followup",                      "patient.days_to_death",                      "patient.stage_event.pathologic_stage",                      "patient.gender") clinical <- do.call(rbind, rep(list(clinical), 5)) rownames(clinical) <- paste("Subject", seq(nrow(clinical)))  # Calculate PSI for skipped exon (SE) and mutually exclusive (MXE) events annot <- readFile("ex_splicing_annotation.RDS") junctionQuant <- readFile("ex_junctionQuant.RDS")  psi <- quantifySplicing(annot, junctionQuant, eventType=c("SE", "MXE")) #> Using 3 of 3 events (100%) whose junctions are present in junction quantification data... #>   |                                        |   0%    |========                                |  20%    |================                        |  40%    |========================                |  60%    |================================        |  80%    |========================================| 100%  #> Using 3 of 3 events (100%) whose junctions are present in junction quantification data... #>   |                                        |   0%    |========                                |  20%    |================                        |  40%    |========================                |  60%    |================================        |  80%    |========================================| 100%   # Match between subjects and samples match <- c("Cancer 1"="Subject 3",            "Cancer 2"="Subject 17",            "Cancer 3"="Subject 21")  eventData <- assignValuePerSubject(psi[3, ], match)  event      <- "days_to_death" timeStart  <- "days_to_death" plotSurvivalPvaluesByCutoff(clinical, eventData, censoring="right",                             event=event, timeStart=timeStart) title: Process survival curves terms to calculate survival curves — processSurvTerms
code: clinical <- read.table(text = "2549   NA ii  female                                 840   NA i   female                                  NA 1204 iv    male                                  NA  383 iv  female                                1293   NA iii   male                                  NA 1355 ii    male") names(clinical) <- c("patient.days_to_last_followup",                      "patient.days_to_death",                      "patient.stage_event.pathologic_stage",                      "patient.gender") timeStart  <- "days_to_death" event      <- "days_to_death" formulaStr <- "patient.stage_event.pathologic_stage + patient.gender" survTerms  <- processSurvTerms(clinical, censoring="right", event, timeStart,                                formulaStr=formulaStr)  # If running multiple times, consider calculating survTime only once survTime <- getAttributesTime(clinical, event, timeStart) for (i in seq(5)) {   survTerms <- processSurvTerms(clinical, censoring="right", event,                                 timeStart, formulaStr=formulaStr,                                 survTime=survTime) }

what: Query the FireBrowse API for TCGA data — queryFirebrowseData
title: Query the FireBrowse API for TCGA data — queryFirebrowseData
text: Query FireBrowse API TCGA data

title: Query the FireBrowse API for TCGA data — queryFirebrowseData
code: queryFirebrowseData(   format = "json",   date = NULL,   cohort = NULL,   data_type = NULL,   tool = NULL,   platform = NULL,   center = NULL,   level = NULL,   protocol = NULL,   page = NULL,   page_size = NULL,   sort_by = NULL )

title: Query the FireBrowse API for TCGA data — queryFirebrowseData
text: format Character: response format JSON, CSV TSV date Character: dates data retrieval FireBrowse (default, uses recent data available) cohort Character: abbreviation cohorts (default, returns data cohorts) data_type Character: data types (optional) tool Character: data produced selected FireBrowse tools (optional) platform Character: data generation platforms (optional) center Character: data generation centres (optional) level Integer: data levels (optional) protocol Character: sample characterization protocols (optional) page Integer: page results return (optional) page_size Integer: number records per page results (optional) sort_by String: column used sort data (default, sort cohort)

title: Query the FireBrowse API for TCGA data — queryFirebrowseData
text: Response FireBrowse API (needs parsed)

title: Query the FireBrowse API for TCGA data — queryFirebrowseData
code: cohort <- getTCGAcohorts()[1] psichomics:::queryFirebrowseData(cohort = names(cohort),                                  data_type = "mRNASeq") #> Response [http://firebrowse.org/api/v1/Archives/StandardData?format=json&date=2016_01_28&cohort=ACC&data_type=mRNASeq] #>   Date: 2023-10-23 07:34 #>   Status: 200 #>   Content-Type: application/json #>   Size: 12.1 kB #> { #>   "StandardData": [ #>     { #>       "active": true, #>       "center": "unc.edu", #>       "cohort": "ACC", #>       "data_type": "mRNASeq", #>       "date": "Thu, 28 Jan 2016 00:00:00 GMT", #>       "filesize": 16560553, #>       "level": 3, #> ...  # Querying for data from a specific date dates <- getTCGAdates() dates <- format(dates, psichomics:::getFirebrowseDateFormat()$query)  psichomics:::queryFirebrowseData(date = dates[2], cohort = names(cohort)) #> Response [http://firebrowse.org/api/v1/Archives/StandardData?format=json&date=2015_11_01&cohort=ACC] #>   Date: 2023-10-23 07:34 #>   Status: 200 #>   Content-Type: application/json #>   Size: 37.2 kB #> { #>   "StandardData": [ #>     { #>       "active": true, #>       "center": "unc.edu", #>       "cohort": "ACC", #>       "data_type": "mRNASeq", #>       "date": "Sun, 01 Nov 2015 00:00:00 GMT", #>       "level": 3, #>       "platform": "illuminahiseq_rnaseqv2", #> ...

  <comment type="function">
    <text evidence="32 34 39 48 52 53 54 55 57 61 62">Involved in double-strand break repair and/or homologous recombination. Binds RAD51 and potentiates recombinational DNA repair by promoting assembly of RAD51 onto single-stranded DNA (ssDNA). Acts by targeting RAD51 to ssDNA over double-stranded DNA, enabling RAD51 to displace replication protein-A (RPA) from ssDNA and stabilizing RAD51-ssDNA filaments by blocking ATP hydrolysis. Part of a PALB2-scaffolded HR complex containing RAD51C and which is thought to play a role in DNA repair by HR. May participate in S phase checkpoint activation. Binds selectively to ssDNA, and to ssDNA in tailed duplexes and replication fork structures. May play a role in the extension step after strand invasion at replication-dependent DNA double-strand breaks; together with PALB2 is involved in both POLH localization at collapsed replication forks and DNA polymerization activity. In concert with NPM1, regulates centrosome duplication. Interacts with the TREX-2 complex (transcription and export complex 2) subunits PCID2 and SEM1, and is required to prevent R-loop-associated DNA damage and thus transcription-associated genomic instability. Silencing of BRCA2 promotes R-loop accumulation at actively transcribed genes in replicating and non-replicating cells, suggesting that BRCA2 mediates the control of R-loop associated genomic instability, independently of its known role in homologous recombination (PubMed:24896180).</text>
  </comment>
  <comment type="subunit">
    <text evidence="1 4 19 32 34 36 41 42 43 44 47 48 49 50 52 53 54 55 57 59 60 61 62 64 65 67">Monomer and dimer (PubMed:20729858). Interacts with RAD51; regulates RAD51 recruitment and function at sites of DNA repair (PubMed:12442171, PubMed:15800615, PubMed:18317453, PubMed:20729832, PubMed:20729859). Interacts with WDR16, USP11, DMC1, ROCK2 and NPM1 (PubMed:15314155, PubMed:15967112, PubMed:20729832, PubMed:21084279). Interacts with SEM1; the interaction masks a nuclear export signal in BRCA2 (PubMed:10373512, PubMed:16205630, PubMed:21719596, PubMed:24013206). Interacts with both nonubiquitinated and monoubiquitinated FANCD2; this complex also includes XRCC3 and phosphorylated FANCG (PubMed:15115758, PubMed:15199141, PubMed:18212739). Part of a BRCA complex containing BRCA1, BRCA2 and PALB2 (PubMed:19369211). Component of the homologous recombination repair (HR) complex composed of ERCC5/XPG, BRCA2, PALB2, DSS1 and RAD51 (PubMed:26833090). Within the complex, interacts with ERCC5/XPG and PALB2 (PubMed:26833090). Interacts directly with PALB2 which may serve as a scaffold for a HR complex containing PALB2, BRCA2, RAD51C, RAD51 and XRCC3 (PubMed:26833090, PubMed:19369211, PubMed:24141787, PubMed:28319063, PubMed:16793542, PubMed:19609323). Interacts with BRCA1 only in the presence of PALB2 which serves as the bridging protein (PubMed:19369211). Interacts with POLH; the interaction is direct (PubMed:24485656). Interacts with the TREX-2 complex subunits PCID2 and SEM1 (PubMed:24896180, PubMed:21719596). Interacts with HSF2BP and BRME1; the interaction with HSF2BP is direct and allows the formation of a ternary complex (PubMed:31242413). The complex BRME1:HSF2BP:BRCA2 interacts with SPATA22, MEIOB and RAD51 (By similarity).</text>
  </comment>

  <comment type="PTM">
    <text evidence="34 41 48">Phosphorylated by ATM upon irradiation-induced DNA damage. Phosphorylation by CHEK1 and CHEK2 regulates interaction with RAD51. Phosphorylation at Ser-3291 by CDK1 and CDK2 is low in S phase when recombination is active, but increases as cells progress towards mitosis; this phosphorylation prevents homologous recombination-dependent repair during S phase and G2 by inhibiting RAD51 binding.</text>
  </comment>
  <comment type="PTM">
    <text evidence="36">Ubiquitinated in the absence of DNA damage; this does not lead to proteasomal degradation. In contrast, ubiquitination in response to DNA damage leads to proteasomal degradation.</text>
  </comment>
  <comment type="disease" evidence="5 7 9 10 11 13 16 18 21 22 24 26 28 30 33 37 44 58 59 71 75 76 77 78">
    <disease id="DI-02602">
      <name>Breast cancer</name>
      <acronym>BC</acronym>
      <description>A common malignancy originating from breast epithelial tissue. Breast neoplasms can be distinguished by their histologic pattern. Invasive ductal carcinoma is by far the most common type. Breast cancer is etiologically and genetically heterogeneous. Important genetic factors have been indicated by familial occurrence and bilateral involvement. Mutations at more than one locus can be involved in different families or even in the same case.</description>
      <dbReference type="MIM" id="114480"/>
    </disease>
    <text>Disease susceptibility is associated with variants affecting the gene represented in this entry.</text>
  </comment>

      <description>A malignant neoplasm of the pancreas. Tumors can arise from both the exocrine and endocrine portions of the pancreas, but 95% of them develop from the exocrine portion, including the ductal epithelium, acinar cells, connective tissue, and lymphatic tissue.</description>

    </disease>

  <comment type="disease">
    <disease id="DI-02603">
      <name>Breast-ovarian cancer, familial, 2</name>
      <acronym>BROVCA2</acronym>
      <description>A condition associated with familial predisposition to cancer of the breast and ovaries. Characteristic features in affected families are an early age of onset of breast cancer (often before age 50), increased chance of bilateral cancers (cancer that develop in both breasts, or both ovaries, independently), frequent occurrence of breast cancer among men, increased incidence of tumors of other specific organs, such as the prostate.</description>
      <dbReference type="MIM" id="612555"/>
    </disease>
    <text>Disease susceptibility is associated with variants affecting the gene represented in this entry.</text>
  </comment>

    <disease id="DI-01601">
      <name>Fanconi anemia complementation group D1</name>
      <acronym>FANCD1</acronym>
      <description>A disorder affecting all bone marrow elements and resulting in anemia, leukopenia and thrombopenia. It is associated with cardiac, renal and limb malformations, dermal pigmentary changes, and a predisposition to the development of malignancies. At the cellular level it is associated with hypersensitivity to DNA-damaging agents, chromosomal instability (increased chromosome breakage) and defective DNA repair.</description>
      <dbReference type="MIM" id="605724"/>
    </disease>
    <text>The disease is caused by variants affecting the gene represented in this entry.</text>

Test Survival Curve Differences — survdiffTerms
text: survTerms survTerms object: survival terms obtained running processSurvTerms (see examples) ... Arguments passed survival::survdiff subset expression indicating subset rows data used fit.  can logical vector (replicated length equal number observations), numeric vector indicating observation numbers included (excluded negative), character vector row names included.  observations included default. na.action missing-data filter function.  applied model.frame subset argument used.  Default options()$na.action. rho scalar parameter controls type test. timefix process times aeqSurv function   eliminate potential roundoff issues.

title: Test Survival Curve Differences — survdiffTerms
text: survfit object. See survfit.object details. Methods defined survfit objects print, plot, lines, points.

title: Test Survival Curve Differences — survdiffTerms
text: function implements G-rho family Harrington Fleming (1982), weights death \(S(t)^\rho\), \(S(t)\) Kaplan-Meier estimate survival. rho = 0 log-rank Mantel-Haenszel test, rho = 1 equivalent Peto & Peto modification Gehan-Wilcoxon test. right hand side formula consists offset term, one sample test done. cause missing values predictors treated separate group, rather omitted, use factor function exclude argument.

title: Test Survival Curve Differences — survdiffTerms
text: Harrington, D. P. Fleming, T. R. (1982). class rank test procedures censored survival data. Biometrika 69, 553-566.

title: Test Survival Curve Differences — survdiffTerms
code: clinical <- read.table(text = "2549   NA ii  female                                 840   NA i   female                                  NA 1204 iv    male                                  NA  383 iv  female                                1293   NA iii   male                                  NA 1355 ii    male") names(clinical) <- c("patient.days_to_last_followup",                      "patient.days_to_death",                      "patient.stage_event.pathologic_stage",                      "patient.gender") timeStart  <- "days_to_death" event      <- "days_to_death" formulaStr <- "patient.stage_event.pathologic_stage + patient.gender" survTerms  <- processSurvTerms(clinical, censoring="right", event, timeStart,                                formulaStr=formulaStr) survdiffTerms(survTerms) #> Call: #> survdiff(formula = survTerms$form, data = survTerms$survTime) #>  #>                                                                 N Observed #> patient.stage_event.pathologic_stage=i, patient.gender=female   1        0 #> patient.stage_event.pathologic_stage=ii, patient.gender=female  1        0 #> patient.stage_event.pathologic_stage=ii, patient.gender=male    1        1 #> patient.stage_event.pathologic_stage=iii, patient.gender=male   1        0 #> patient.stage_event.pathologic_stage=iv, patient.gender=female  1        1 #> patient.stage_event.pathologic_stage=iv, patient.gender=male    1        1 #>                                                                 Expected #> patient.stage_event.pathologic_stage=i, patient.gender=female      0.167 #> patient.stage_event.pathologic_stage=ii, patient.gender=female     0.917 #> patient.stage_event.pathologic_stage=ii, patient.gender=male       0.917 #> patient.stage_event.pathologic_stage=iii, patient.gender=male      0.417 #> patient.stage_event.pathologic_stage=iv, patient.gender=female     0.167 #> patient.stage_event.pathologic_stage=iv, patient.gender=male       0.417 #>                                                                 (O-E)^2/E #> patient.stage_event.pathologic_stage=i, patient.gender=female     0.16667 #> patient.stage_event.pathologic_stage=ii, patient.gender=female    0.91667 #> patient.stage_event.pathologic_stage=ii, patient.gender=male      0.00758 #> patient.stage_event.pathologic_stage=iii, patient.gender=male     0.41667 #> patient.stage_event.pathologic_stage=iv, patient.gender=female    4.16667 #> patient.stage_event.pathologic_stage=iv, patient.gender=male      0.81667 #>                                                                 (O-E)^2/V #> patient.stage_event.pathologic_stage=i, patient.gender=female       0.200 #> patient.stage_event.pathologic_stage=ii, patient.gender=female      1.458 #> patient.stage_event.pathologic_stage=ii, patient.gender=male        0.012 #> patient.stage_event.pathologic_stage=iii, patient.gender=male       0.532 #> patient.stage_event.pathologic_stage=iv, patient.gender=female      5.000 #> patient.stage_event.pathologic_stage=iv, patient.gender=male        1.043 #>  #>  Chisq= 7.3  on 5 degrees of freedom, p= 0.2

title: Create survival curves — survfit.survTerms
text: survival curve based tabulation number risk   number events unique death time.  time floating   point number definition "unique" subject interpretation.   code uses factor() define set.   details see documentation appropriate method, .e.,   ?survfit.formula ?survfit.coxph. survfit object may contain single curve, set curves,   matrix curves.   Predicted curves coxph model one row   stratum Cox model fit one column specified   covariate set.   Curves multi-state model one row stratum   column state, strata correspond predictors   right hand side equation.  default printing plotting   order curves column, matrices. Curves can subscripted using either single double subscript.   set curves matrix, , one   dimensions 1 code allows single subscript used.   (, quite general using single subscript   numeric matrix.)

title: Create survival curves — survfit.survTerms
code: library("survival") clinical <- read.table(text = "2549   NA ii  female                                 840   NA i   female                                  NA 1204 iv    male                                  NA  383 iv  female                                1293   NA iii   male                                  NA 1355 ii    male") names(clinical) <- c("patient.days_to_last_followup",                      "patient.days_to_death",                      "patient.stage_event.pathologic_stage",                      "patient.gender") timeStart  <- "days_to_death" event      <- "days_to_death" formulaStr <- "patient.stage_event.pathologic_stage + patient.gender" survTerms  <- processSurvTerms(clinical, censoring="right", event, timeStart,                                formulaStr=formulaStr) survfit(survTerms) #> Call: survfit(formula = survTerms$form, data = survTerms$survTime) #>  #>                                                                 n events median #> patient.stage_event.pathologic_stage=i, patient.gender=female   1      0     NA #> patient.stage_event.pathologic_stage=ii, patient.gender=female  1      0     NA #> code: words <- c("tumor_stage", "age", "gender") psichomics:::textSuggestions("textareaid", words) #> <script> textareaid_words = ["tumor_stage", "age", "gender"]; $("#textareaid").textcomplete([{ #>             match: /([a-zA-Z0-9_\.]{1,})$/, #>             search: function(term, callback) { #>                 var words = textareaid_words, sorted = []; #>                 for (i = 0; i < words.length; i++) { #>                     sorted[i] = fuzzy(words[i], term); #>                 } #>                 sorted.sort(fuzzy.matchComparator); #>                 sorted = sorted.map(function(i) { return i.term; }); #>                 callback(sorted); #>             }, #>             index: 1, #>             cache: true, #>             replace: function(word) { #>             return word + " "; #>         }}], { noResultsMessage: "No matching value"}); </script>
